name: Listen for and handle input from ALL pages
info:
# Handling input

We get 1 message for EVERY input changed (*not* 1 msg per page).

The JSON returned to this ws contains the page it was on, 
any url parameters and the specific input that was changed.

Finding the input field name and the value can be a challange since
it depends heavily on the HTML used.

For normal INPUT fields we recieve:
```
{
	'timestamp' 	: e.timeStamp,
	// What type of input field
	'type' 			: e.target.type,
	// ID of the form this input field belongs to
	'frmId'			: $( this ).closest('form').attr('id'),
	// Name/ID of the element one or both may be set
	'name' 			: $( this ).prop("name"),
	'id' 			: $( this ).prop("id"),
	'willValidate' 	: e.target.willValidate,
	'placeHolder' 	: e.target.placeHolder,
	'defaultValue' 	: e.target.defaultValue,
	// Value is only ever a singleton string. Use val for multi-values
	'value' 		: e.target.value, // only ever returns 1 value (string)
	'valueAsNumber' : e.target.valueAsNumber,
	// Will be on/off for switches/checkboxes
	'checked' 		: $( this ).prop("checked"),
	// returns an array for multi-selects
	'val' 			: $( this ).val(),
	// Where are we? Used on server to id which page this is from
	'url'			: location.pathname,
	'query'			: location.search
}
```

But Zurb foundation also has a "slider" which isn't an input field, this returns:

```
{
	'timestamp' : e.timeStamp,
	'type' 		: 'slider',
	'frmId'		: $( this ).closest('form').attr('id'),
	'id' 		: $( this ).prop("id"),
	'value' 	: $( this ).attr('data-slider'),
	'val' 		: $( this ).attr('data-slider'),
	'url'		: location.pathname,
	'query'		: location.search
}
```

# How do we tie this to a specific client session?

e.g. a specific instance of a page request.

We don't!

The trick is to accept input, do something, send output - 
websockets ensures the send is to the same client unless
the client id is deleted (in which case it is broadcast).

There is no link between the socket and the original page
request/response.

We could set an ID in the original response and then send
that back with the socket message. But there will be issues
of security to deal with (*) and a need to maintain a list (db)
of active clients. Better to try to avoid this overhead.

(*) Random ID (token) - should seed with clients IP address 
and other  info to ensure unquiquness to a single client
connection. Also need to age the token (expire it) and to
validate that subsequent reciepts of the token come from the
correct client.

name: Set topic: INPUT/<url page name>

func: rbe

This gets the input from the face tracking app at https://raspberrypi.local/face-tracker/#1 (phone 1)
info: Note: you must be connected directly to the VizBlocks network in order for the face tracker app to work. You also need to specify a phone id in the url using `#[phone id]`, e.g. `#1` for phone 1.

label: Set the angle for the eyebrows

name: Face 1
func:
let topic = msg.topic;
let payload = msg.payload;

let currentEmotion = flow.get('face1_' + 'currentEmotion') || 'face1_emotion1'

switch (topic) {
    case 'name':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, payload)
        break
    case 'l_eye_colour':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, payload)
        break
    case 'l_eye_count':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, payload)
        break
    case 'r_eye_colour':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, payload)
        break
    case 'r_eye_count':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, payload)
        break
    case 'l_eyebrow_angle':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + 'l_eyebrow_angle', payload)
        break
    case 'r_eyebrow_angle':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, msg.payload)
        break
    case 'mouth_angle':
        flow.set(currentEmotion + '_' + topic, msg.payload)
        break
    case 'l_eyebrow_command':
        break
    case 'r_eyebrow_command':
        break
    case 'l_eye_command':
        break
    case 'r_eye_command':
        break
    case 'mouth':
        break
}

return {topic: currentEmotion,payload: topic + '_' + payload}

//flow.set('angry' + msg.topic, msg.payload)

window redirect
format:
<script>
(function(scope) {
    scope.$watch('msg.payload', function(data) {
        if (data == "Face-Tracker") {
          //window.open("https://www.nodered.org");
          window.location.href = "https://192.168.4.1/face-tracker/";
        } 
        if (data == "Weather") {
          //window.open("https://github.com/node-red");
          window.location.href = "https://192.168.4.1/face-tracker/dataset.html ";
        } 
    });
})(scope);
</script>

Double-click on this inject node and edit the command you'd like to send to the vizblock
info: Double-click on this inject node and edit the command you'd like to send to the vizblock

name: Double-click on this MQTT send node and change the topic to the name of the VizBlock you want to control
CLICK ME and read instructions in the right-hand panel
info:
# Instructions

This flow lets you test the basic functionality of this remote Node-Red and MQTT server. 

Before starting, check that the purple MQTT send node says `connected` beneath it. If not, double click the node to open its settings, then click the pencil icon next to the server input, then go to the security tab and make sure the username and password is entered for the MQTT broker.

## Setting up your VizBlock

In order for a the vizblock to work with this remote server, you will need configure the VizBlock (using Arduino code) so that it:
- a) connects to a WiFi network with internet access.
- b) connects to the remote MQTT server.

You can do this by editing the block configuration in the following lines:

```
VizBlock node(
  "null",       // Our ID
  "<wifi_net>",  //Wifi Access Point
  "<wifi_password>",  //WiFi Password
  "vizblocks-server.creativeinformatics.org",//IP address of Node RED server
   8883,         //Port for Node RED server
   "<mqtt_user>",  //MQTT username
   "<mqtt_password>",    //MQTT password
   "<F7:AD:10:85:97:1E:F8:68:08:17:A3:DC:68:F9:C3:42:DE:C9:A3:F8>" // SHA1 fingerprint (for mqtt server)
  );
```

Replace all of the settings in `<>` with your values (or those provided to you). To get the SHA1 fingerprint you can use the following command (on Mac/Linux):

```bash
openssl s_client -connect vizblocks-server.creativeinformatics.org:8883 < /dev/null 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -fingerprint -noout -in /dev/stdin
```

## Running a test
Double click on the blue input node to open its setting tab, then enter the command you'd like to send to the VizBlock in the `msg.payload` field.

Double click on the purple MQTT node and enter the name of the VizBlock you'd like to control in the Topic field.

Click **Deploy** in the top right corner, then click the button to the right of the input node to send commands to your VizBlock.
